climbs.name: Spanking The Shirken
climbs.fa: Mike Fogarty, Dave Cox, Shawn Scott, Mark Berryhill.

content.location:
Just left of falling sherkin

60 meter rope will get you down

content.description: This makes for a good introduction to the crag. Nothing special here, just classic friction moves on slick desert granite.
content.location: See photos. Furthest left route on the main wall.

content.description: Fun slabby, slopey edges That lead to the top of the block where you set your own anchor.  Note the route title and beware!
content.protection: Quickdraws for six bolts and medium to small cams for the anchor.
content.location: Right of center on the block.

climbs.name: Slaughtumn
climbs.fa: John Shippling, Rolf Rybak, Autumn Corrow, Tim Pinar, Todd Gordon

content.description: This is the third bolted route from the left. Cool slabby climbing on featured and beautiful rock in a wonderful setting.
content.location: Located about 15-20 feet left of Spankin' the Sherkin. Rap or lower off double bolts with rings. Careful when lowering. Swing off to the left on the shoulder as the climb is about 110 feet long! Tie a knot in the end of the rope. Don't lower off the end of the rope!

content.description: This large boulder gets missed when approaching the imposing wall.  Too bad...not a bad line to warm up on.
content.protection: Four QDs and runners for the anchor.
content.location: About 150 meters below the main wall and on the far right of the canyon.  This is an obvious LARGE boulder just right of the trail up.

content.description: Five bolts up face without using arete.
content.protection: Quickdraws and medium to small cams for anchor.

climbs.name: La Vena Negra
climbs.fa: Mike Rigney, Rob Stauder, Bob Cable & Brad Singer, 1997

content.description:
Pitch 1: Seven bolts lead up to a corner, over left and up to a two bolt anchor.

Pitch 2: Six bolts up and right, then left to a two bolt anchor; this is the crux pitch.

Pitch 3: Run out 5.6 past three bolts to a two bolt anchor.

Pitch 4:Â  Run out 5.6 arching right to the top of

History Repeats Itself

, only one bolt.
content.location: Middle of the face at the obvious black waterstreak.

climbs.name: Flying Sheep
climbs.fa: Brent Inghram, Kris Solem and Roy Suggett

content.description: Follow eight bolts to chains.  Two ropes needed to rap. The crux is between the third and forth bolt. Fun!
content.location: Right side of the falls up a narrow slab.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Three bolts to top of block and set your own anchor.

Pitch 2: Some medium cams then six bolts to a two bolt anchor (crux pitch).

Pitch 3: Three bolts with 5.8 climbing.

Pitch 4: Run out 5.7 with a crack that takes small to medium wires.
content.protection: Quickdraws, runners, small to medium cams and wires.
content.location: Just right of the center of the face

content.description: Six bolts straight up to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Middle of the block and over on to the main face.

content.description:
An easy slabby route with the crux at the start

Pitch 1: 4 bolts to an anchor (90 feet)

Pitch 2: 6 bolts to an anchor (115 feet)

The Charmed Life

is a long pitch of desert slab. Like its neighbouring routes, it's a real calf-burner. It was bolted ground-up so the spacing may be considered a little spicy for some. Not dangerous at all, but perhaps just exciting enough to make it memorable.

Route:

Start up a shallow left-facing crescent which soon fizzles out, leaving you with a seemingly endless friction romp. Slightly crispy stone at the 3rd bolt gradually gives way to a smooth varnished slab with very few features. At the 8th bolt, surmount the undercut basalt dike and finish on an exfoliating slab.

Descent:

Rappel from the two-bolt ring anchor. Read below:

With one 60m rope you will need to stop halfway down at the top-anchor for

So Rebel

(climber's left).

With one 70m rope you can make it to the ground but you must trend climber's left to land on higher ground. -

knot your ends!!!

With two ropes you will easily make it all the way down.

To lower off and thus leave a toprope setup, keep the following things in mind:

You need a 70m rope for this.

Construct your anchor with a >20-foot length of cordelette.

Have the belayer scramble a little ways up and left along the base of the wall to a higher position.

Knot the end for safety!
content.location: See photos. This route is second-from-the-left on the far left side of the wall. Look for the first bolt in a shallow, left-facing crescent.

content.description: Turning the corner of the undercling is the 5.8 move.
content.location: Far left of block on main face

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb past a bolt (the crux) into a shallow left facing dihedral that takes gear to a two bolt anchor.

Pitch 2: Slab climbing past 4 bolts to an anchor.

Pitch 1: Climb the arete past four bolts (the crack can also take gear, medium to large cams) to a ledge at far right of the block.

Pitch 2: Up and right past five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Quickdraws, runners, small to large cams.
